awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation: Understanding the Impact of Institutional Supports on the Motivation, Belonging, Identity Development, and Persistence of Engineering Students
awd_abstract_narration:
Educating a diverse, creative, engaged, and skilled cohort of engineering students is the central mission of undergraduate engineering programs. Achieving this mission is essential to providing the engineering workforce of the future. Unfortunately, persistence of engineering students to graduation remains undesirably low, despite the programs and resources that universities and colleges of engineering put in place to support students' success. This project examines whether and how students' use of these institutional resources enhances their persistence and success as engineering students. Knowledge and insights gained from this research will improve the ability of institutions to design their programs to maximize the benefits to their student population. 

The project investigates academic and co-curricular factors associated with students' engineering identity, their sense of belonging in college, and their engineering-related motivation. Drawing from a longitudinal dataset tracking undergraduates from the start of college through graduation, the project considers: i) how the use of institutional supports predicts students' engineering-related motivation, belonging, and identity development over time, ii) how the use of institutional supports predicts persistence, and iii) whether the effects on persistence are mediated through changes in students' psychological processes. The results of this work will inform the field about the underlying mechanisms associated with persistence, providing much needed insights into the reasons why these institutional supports may (or may not) be effective, with direct application to the future development of institutional supports that more effectively support persistence. An examination of whether certain institutional support structures are particularly helpful to specific groups (e.g., by gender, race/ethnicity, first-generation college student) will provide valuable, generalizable insights for targeted retention efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The project examined how academic and co-curricular activities were associated with students' engineering-related identity, motivation, and feelings of belonging, as well as their persistence in engineering. Our goal was to identify whether and how programs that are designed to support student success also support students' motivation. The proposed work supported an important collaboration between the PI, from the College of Engineering, and the co-PI/Mentor, from the College of Education. The results from the project have identified a number of activities that have measureable impacts on students' motivation and success. Some of our published results are highlighted below.

Robinson et al. 2022. Instructional Supports for Motivation Trajectories in Introductory College Engineering. AERA Open. 8. https://doi.org/10.1177/23328584221083662
This study examined relations between perceived motivational supports, year-long trajectories of expectancy for success and three task values, and grades among students in a large, gateway engineering course. Results indicated that students with higher motivation at the beginning of the year tended to perceive their class as more motivationally supportive. Controlling for relations between initial motivation and perceptions, perceived instructional supports for mastery goals, autonomy, and competence predicted more positive trajectories of all three task values. Conversely, higher perceived instructor performance goals negatively predicted grades and the slopes of self-efficacy and interest value. The results demonstrated the importance students place on certain motivationally supportive practices in promoting students' STEM motivation trajectories.

Lee et al. (2022). The multiplicative function of expectancy and value in predicting engineering students' choice, persistence, and performance. Journal of Engineering Education. 111(3): 531 to 553.
In this study, we tested how engineering academic self-efficacy (expectancy), values/costs, and their interactions predicted engineering-related outcomes. We hypothesized that there would be significant interactions between self-efficacy and values/costs in predicting engineering persistence and academic success. In line with our hypothesis, we did find significant interactions between self-efficacy and values (interest and utility only) but not for self-efficacy and attainment value or costs. Put another way, feeling both competent in engineering and highly valuing engineering simultaneously were related to higher engineering persistence, as compared to either feeling competent or valuing engineering alone. The findings inform practice by highlighting the importance of supporting both expectancy and values when intervening to support engineering persistence.

As stated above, the project supported the PI in gaining a deeper understanding of the science of motivation. The project also supported 15 undergraduate students and 5 graduate students (including students from both the College of Engineering and the College of Education), who engaged in various aspects of the project.

Intellectual Merit: The project resulted in new understanding of the means by which engineering students' motivation and self-efficacy can be supported. In particular, we identified critical activities early in students' first year that forestall declines in motivation, such as emphasizing mastery learning orientation in first-year courses. As we continue to generate results from the data gathered during this project, we anticipate being able to identify additional activities, especially later in students' undergraduate careers, that are important for maximizing motivation and self-efficacy.

Broader Impacts: As stated above, the project has identified a number of means of supporting engineering students' motivation. These results have been disseminated broadly in the educational psychology and engineering communities, including through a highly viewed video presented at the 2022 ASEE Annual Conference and Exposition. We anticipate that our results will inform improvements in engineering programs and STEM programs more broadly. Additionally, the project trained the PI in social science methods for collecting, analyzing, and disseminating data regarding student motivation. This has led to direct improvements in the PI's role as an instructor but will also serve as the basis for continued collaboration between the PI and co-PI/Mentor. Finally, the project supported the education and training of five graduate students, from the College of Engineering and College of Education, and 15 undergraduate students, whose understanding of these methods and the unique aspects of undergraduate engineering education will allow them to engage in this important research as they continue in their careers.


Last Modified: 04/30/2023
Modified by: Stephen P Walton
